I was eager to play this back when it was first released because I loved the original MW2 but this one was lackluster of a sequel. Here's my experience with this game so far, I've been playing it from release when it was on the god-awful CoD HQ thing.

First, the campaign was good but didn't live up to the hype. Still not a bad campaign at all and introduced new characters, new elements, new mechanics, but Infinity Ward's choices regarding certain character development aspects were not the most ideal.

Multiplayer was fun & hard to master. Which to me was great considering that I hate Treyarch's omni-movement thing that made everyone running around, jumping and sliding with almost 100% aiming accuracy which is fucking insane.

This game also came with a co-op mode divided to co-op missions or (special ops) and Raids. The co-op missions were like normal MW co-op we've seen before, they were basically multiple missions that continue on the story and can be played with your buddies. Raids however, were something different and I personally like it so much. The Raids were spread across 4 episodes, each episode can be played on normal difficulty or veteran difficulty with each one granting different rewards that can be used in-game. The gameplay was tactical and requires syncing with your squad mates to solve puzzles and coordinate objectives. And each episode bridges the story gab between MW 1 (2019) and this one (MW 2 2022). The only obstacle I had is that it must be played with two other players, you can't just solo it by yourself. 3 players go in with each one choosing a class between 3 classes.

And my personal favorite was the DMZ mode. This one remained in beta for the entirety of the game, still to this day in beta even. It was basically a PvPvE extraction shooter with a CoD flavor. It still get recycled to this day with the MWZ mode in MW3 and End Game mode in Avalon for Black Ops 7 currently. This mode would've been a killer mode if Activision gave it a bit more caring and more attention but I guess they were just experimenting stuff.

Overall, the game is good. Don't expect too much from it if you come from the OG CoD era, you'll be disappointed. Currently, the game looks dead, multiplayer doesn't have much players except for the Shipment playlist and couple other modes. DMZ still have some popularity and co-op/raid modes are basically unplayable if you don't have friends to play with.

Personally, I would give this one a 7.5/10 even though I liked it overall. But it could've been way more enjoyable.

I wanted to lay out all the specifics of the game here for anyone thinking to get this game on sale (definitely don't get it for full price) hope this helps. :)

[b]Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II ‚Äì Tactical, Cinematic, and Incredibly Addictive[/b]

[i]Modern Warfare II[/i] delivers one of the most polished and refined shooter experiences in the franchise‚Äôs history. From the moment the campaign begins, the game showcases its mastery of tension, weight, and immersive action. Each mission feels handcrafted, cinematic, and grounded, blending stealth, urban warfare, and high-stakes global operations with seamless pacing and emotional impact.

Task Force 141 returns better than ever. Ghost, Soap, Price, Gaz ‚Äî every character has purpose, chemistry, and memorable dialogue that builds on the legacy of Modern Warfare while paving new ground. The writing keeps the story sharp and unpredictable, and the character interactions feel natural rather than forced. This is a campaign driven not just by explosions, but by personalities, loyalty, and strategy.

Gameplay is fast, fluid, and incredibly satisfying. Gunplay has weight and precision ‚Äî every trigger pull and reload animation feels meticulous. Whether you‚Äôre breaching buildings, clearing oil tankers, sniping from extreme distances, or navigating stealth-focused operations, the game constantly shifts tone and playstyle without ever losing intensity. Enemy AI is aggressive and tactical, forcing you to adapt and think rather than simply run forward.

Visually, the game is stunning. Lighting, weapon detail, character models, night vision, and weather effects push immersion to another level. Combined with the outstanding sound design ‚Äî punchy gunfire, echoing footsteps, and powerful explosions ‚Äî the campaign feels cinematic from start to finish.

Multiplayer and co-op modes reinforce the experience with deep progression, smooth movement, and some of the most polished maps in recent COD history. Weapon customization through the Gunsmith system is addictive and promotes experimentation without overwhelming complexity.

[i]Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II[/i] succeeds because it respects both intensity and realism. It‚Äôs not afraid to slow down for stealth, speed up for chaos, or hit hard emotionally when it counts.

This is COD at its sharpest ‚Äî cinematic, tactical, and endlessly replayable.
A must-play for campaign lovers and competitive shooter fans alike.

My review will only touch on the Campaign portion of the game. 

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II (2022) is a solid sequel that offers another rich, action packed gameplay experience. The story differs in setting from the first game, offering a chance to experience new locations that the franchise hasn't really explored before. While the majority of the characters from the first game return, a handful of new ones are also introduced (both allies and enemies). The cut-scenes and voice acting are once again top notch. The game isn't very long, it hits that 8 to 10 hour COD campaign sweetspot. While COD campaigns can be hit or miss, this one is of high quality and is executed well. It'll keep you engaged the entire time, and doesn't lull or slowdown. It does what you have come to expect of a good Call of Duty campaign mode. 

While I do recommend this game for the campaign alone (and the co-op experience, if you can find a lobby or friends to play with), I find it hard to recommend at the current sale price of $35.99 CAD (~$27.99 USD). It would seem that the days of Activision discounting Call of Duty games to under $20, is gone. My opinion is that $20 is what it's worth.

No updates, constantly crashing, taking up over 100GB on my drive, and consistent bugs since day 1. I spent $120 on this game, and I'm never doing it again. Activision and all of their associated titles are never getting another cent from me or anyone I can convince otherwise. 

I've racked up hundreds of hours in this game. So please listen devs, management, and prospective customers when I say this:
1. The menus seem to get more complicated every 6 months for no apparent reason, with the actual game modes getting more obfuscated and harder to find. Imagine the Hulu UI, but worse.
2. The "permanently online" thing is a terrible idea that constantly drops me from games, and I'm starting to think its the game servers more than my internet connection. Even in "safe mode" the game will still crash, and not show any sort of error report.
3. When I bought the game (for an obscene price), it would regularly tell me that I needed to "purchase a pass" to access the thing I'd bought. Sometimes it would let me in, sometimes it would boot me and crash my game. I don't believe this is a me issue. 
4. Your cheater/issue submission system is a joke and goes nowhere, with people still consistently cheating and getting away with it. If you do submit an issue/bug, you don't get any form of correspondence to say so, which makes me think it all gets sent immediately to the recycle bin.
5. Your inability to have any of your products work with 2 monitors is bewildering. Every, and I mean EVERY other game I own can easily Alt+Tab into another window to say change music, or an episode, or do something without causing everything to go black and run the risk of a game crash (or a system crash, which I've had a few times, and I'm confident my system is stable so it's likely the shitty product)
6. This new direction with AI generated art? What's going on with that? Nobody wants overpriced AI generated garbage from a company owned by a major asshole
7. The install size. Please. Why does it need to be so big. Please for the love of all in this world stop blowing up the file sizes. It increases system storage needs, system load in operation, and most people can't even render it properly. Why?

As far as I can tell, all of your products are developed in the least efficient way imaginable, and it causes deep issues in the final product that greatly impacts the users overall.

Never buying a game from this company again and I hope this review has helped you to come to the same conclusion. Eat shit Activision.

When DMZ first launched, it brought something truly fresh to the Call of Duty series a tactical extraction shooter built on Warzone‚Äôs foundation, combining open-world missions, PvE + PvP combat, and looting systems with immense potential. Unfortunately, over time that potential has been squandered due to severe negligence in player security, exploit control, and developer support.

---

1. Rampant Hacking and Lack of Effective Anti-Cheat

DMZ has become overrun with cheaters, making legitimate play increasingly impossible. Despite the presence of the Ricochet anti-cheat system, it has proven largely ineffective:

Hackers routinely join multiple games without any bans, even when they are blatantly using aimbots, wallhacks, and ESP tools.
When bans do occur, they are meaningless. Since the game is free to play, cheaters can simply create a new account and re-enter within minutes there is no deterrent or accountability.
No paywall = no consequence. Without even a minimal entry cost, bad actors can exploit the system endlessly, ruining match integrity for everyone else.
Players have repeatedly reported these problems through official channels, yet there has been little to no visible improvement.

This creates a cycle where legitimate players are punished by an environment that rewards exploiters and discourages long-term investment in the game.

---

2. Glitches and Exploits Left Unaddressed

In addition to cheating, DMZ suffers from a staggering number of gameplay-breaking glitches that have persisted across multiple seasons:

Item duplication exploits allow players to infinitely duplicate contraband weapons, killstreaks, and rare items.
Mission and extraction bugs frequently cause players to lose progression or crash mid-match.
Map and terrain exploits enable unfair visibility or invulnerability advantages.

These issues are well-known within the community, and yet patches and developer updates rarely prioritize them. Players exploiting these bugs gain massive unfair advantages while honest players suffer repeated losses and frustration.

---

3. Lack of Developer Support and Communication

The silence from the developers has been perhaps the most damaging aspect of DMZ‚Äôs decline. Once promoted as an evolving, supported mode with regular updates and balancing, it now feels abandoned:

There are no consistent balance changes, bug fixes, or community updates.
Player feedback regarding cheating and glitches has gone largely ignored.
Community trust has eroded due to broken promises and minimal transparency about the mode‚Äôs future.

It‚Äôs disheartening to watch a game that once showed such promise fall into neglect simply because support and accountability disappeared.

---

4. Impact on Player Experience

The current state of DMZ is demoralizing for long-time fans. What was once a tense, strategic, and rewarding extraction experience has devolved into chaos and exploitation. Legitimate players now struggle to find fair matches or meaningful progression. Many have left the game entirely, turning to other titles with stronger anti-cheat systems and active developer engagement.

---

5. Suggestions for Improvement

If DMZ is ever to recover, the following changes are essential:

1. Implement a paywall or access requirement even a small purchase barrier would significantly reduce the influx of new hacker accounts.
2. Strengthen and actively monitor anti-cheat enforcement with real-time detection and permanent hardware bans.
3. Prioritize exploit and duplication fixes with transparent patch notes and consistent maintenance.
4. Re-establish developer communication with a dedicated DMZ team providing regular updates and community Q&As.

Without these steps, DMZ risks total collapse as its player base continues to erode.

---

Conclusion

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II‚Äôs DMZ mode had the foundation to become one of the best extraction shooters in the market. Instead, it has been crippled by rampant cheating, unpatched exploits, and a lack of developer accountability.

It‚Äôs heartbreaking to watch something that once brought players together for strategic, adrenaline-filled sessions become unplayable due to neglect. With proper attention, DMZ could still be redeemed but until real action is taken, many loyal fans have no choice but to walk away.
